awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Electro-Mechanical Interactions in Biological Membranes
awd_abstract_narration:
Lipid membranes form the envelope surrounding the interior of biological cells. These membranes exhibit
unique mechanical and electrical properties that interact in such a way as to facilitate a wide range of
biological processes. The structure of the lipid molecules that constitute these membranes imparts unusual
mechanical behavior resembling that of liquid crystals, a phase of matter intermediate between conventional
solids and liquids. Another basic feature of plasma membranes is a negatively charged inner layer of lipid
molecules. These charged lipids diffuse on the membrane surface in response to physical forces. In turn,
charged lipids play a significant role in regulating the functionality of membrane-embedded protein
structures. The objective of this project is to formulate and employ mathematical and computational models
to investigate electro-mechanical interactions of lipid-protein systems. Insights gained from the project will
lead to improved understanding of physical processes occurring at the cellular level. This in turn is expected
to enhance understanding of the mechanisms underlying lipid-associated diseases and the efficacy of drug
therapies. Thus, the project will promote the progress of fundamental science and advance national
priorities in the critical area of healthcare. The project combines expertise in various branches of physics,
structural engineering and cellular biology. It will provide advanced training to a diverse group of students
and thereby enhance U.S. global competitiveness by contributing to the establishment of a new generation
of interdisciplinary scientists and engineers.

This project will provide the mathematical framework to describe the fundamental interactions of charged
lipids and proteins in biological membranes. It will culminate in a predictive tool for the simulation of the
microscopic electromechanical interactions responsible for a host of cellular functions. Its novel features
include the use of continuum theory and molecular dynamics modeling of the coupled interplay between
membrane deformation at the lipid-protein interfaces, diffusion of charged lipids and proteins, and the
quantification of the role of electric fields on the behavior of the combined system. The derived framework
would also assist researchers in the mechanics and material science communities to model complex 2D
interfaces.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit: The research objective of this project was to investigate the electromechanical response of lipid membranes. The findings from this grant are changing the way we understand membrane-electric field interactions. For nearly five decades, the primary working model suggested that the membranes get polarized normal to the membrane surface in response to normal electric fields. This model formed the backbone of the traditional flexoelectric model for lipid membranes. We performed atomistic and coarse-grained simulations to quantify polarization in flat and curved membranes. Our simulations revealed that the primary polarization in membranes is tangential to the membrane surface. In fact, our study showed that normal electric field had minimal impact on the membrane polarization. In another study we quantified the effect of electric field on membrane properties. Our study showed that lateral electric field can modulate phase transition from gel to fluid state in lipid membranes. Normal electric field, in contrast, had minimal impact on phase transition. This finding has important consequences as it suggests that endogenous and exogenous electric fields can regulate the physical property of the membranes, thereby controlling numerous membrane-protein interactions in cells that determine both the structure and the function of cells and cellular organelles. In addition, we investigated the electromechanical interactions of a model voltage-sensitive ion channel with the surrounding membrane. Our study shows the mechanisms by which electrical and mechanical properties can cooperatively modulate the kinematics of channel proteins. This project also supported studies to investigate the consequences of nanoarchitecture and topology on the mechanics of ion channels and shell structures. 

Broader Impact: Overall, our work sets the foundation to revisit our current understanding of the electromechanical processes associated with cellular membranes. The findings from the project would be valuable in gaining deeper mechanistic insights into a wide variety of biophysical processes such as cell motility, transport of nutrients and drugs, and signaling pathways in cells. The findings can help design improved biomedical strategies for membrane-dependent therapeutics of neurological disorders and electric field-dependent drug discovery protocols. Our findings on mechano-geometry will promote designs of novel biophysical sensors and structures for extreme mechanical environment. The project has supported several graduate students towards the fulfillment of their PhD research in the areas of biophysics and computational mechanics at the University of Houston. The project has also supported and trained several undergraduate students from underrepresented groups in the areas of applied mechanics and data analysis. One of these students won the 2023 BEYA (Black Engineers of the Year Awards) Student Academic Award. A team of undergraduate researchers used their analytical skills to investigate the road safety conditions in the Houston area. Their analysis was showcased by five media channels and was shared with the city of Houston. 


Last Modified: 12/29/2023
Modified by: Ashutosh Agrawal
